summaryInsights.title: ER overutilization and avoidable admits driving ~$600–900M
summaryInsights.detail: Illinois spend is inflated by persistent ED-to-inpatient conversion and short-stay admits, with DRGs 291/292 (heart failure/shock) and sepsis-related admissions rising faster than member growth; tightening medical necessity and short-stay review in Chicagoland is the fastest lever.

summaryInsights.title: Outpatient imaging escalation exploiting auth weak points
summaryInsights.detail: Advanced imaging volume (MRI/CT—CPT 70551–70553, 74176–74178) is concentrated in a small set of outpatient centers where prior-auth exceptions and resubmission patterns are converting denials to approvals; targeted pre-pay imaging edits and exception policy hardening will reduce forecast pressure.

summaryInsights.title: Infusion and specialty drug spend drifting to high-cost settings
summaryInsights.detail: Specialty infusion claims show site-of-care drift toward higher-cost hospital outpatient settings (key J-code families), indicating enforcement gaps in site-of-care and step-therapy policies; redirecting volume to compliant lower-cost settings is a controllable lever embedded in the state forecast.

summaryInsights.title: Appeal-driven denial leakage raising realized paid rate
summaryInsights.detail: A subset of denied Illinois claims repeatedly flips to paid status through sequencing and coding variation, weakening baseline denial yield assumptions; tightening appeal thresholds and adding denial-resistance rules for the highest-leak pathways will bring paid rate back in line.

summaryInsights.title: Network spillover risk through shared billing operations
summaryInsights.detail: Providers connected via common billing operations show near-identical CPT sequencing and appeal success, creating spillover risk across Illinois networks; isolating and intervening on these clusters will prevent local tactics from becoming statewide trend.

summaryInsights.title: Behavior-driven spend distorting IL trend assumptions
summaryInsights.detail: After controlling for utilization and morbidity, $1.5–2.5B of Illinois projected spend appears driven by controllable provider behavior in ED admits, imaging, and outpatient infusions rather than organic clinical demand growth.
